{"doc":{"info":{"calaisRequestID":"26195e41-add6-b221-46f2-2d0d606ddbbe","id":"http://id.opencalais.com/eXhbvcaK980lcPadKUG9qg","docId":"http://d.opencalais.com/dochash-1/3c383f98-33c0-3d34-a62b-77ce355cff57","document":" ï¿¼THE GO-BETWEEN S My fiance, bitchy to the last, gave me as a parting gift a parrot whose only tongue was Greek. But by the way it spoke, I felt quite sure the bird insulted me. His spiteful eye shot messages of hate, and at the end of every speech he climaxed on a fusillade of shrieks. I bought a textbook on demotic Greek; I joined a class; struck up a loose rapport with waiters in a local Greek cafe (a grave mistake - but that's another tale) still nobody could give a clear account of what the bird's discourse could mean. At length I taught him certain Anglo-Saxon words and sent him back by cab. He disappeared shouting the worst obscenities I knew, turning the air a rich and vibrant blue.
